Under the superintendence and instruction OF
WILLIAM SHERER, assisted by accomplished
female teachers.


The course of instruction pursued at TINS sem
;,,r,- comprises all the useful, and most OF the
ornamental branches of female education. The
daily exercises are photography, Reading, Writ
;nr. Arithmetic, English Grammar, Rhetoric;
Geography and History, ancient and modern,
with constant reference to the best maps and
charts: Construction of maps; use OF the Globes;
Natural History; Natural Philosophy, including
Astronomy and Chemistry, Elements ot Moral
Science


TfeekiD Egerc;Ses. --Biblical Rccitations; Evi-
dences OF Christianity; Letter Writing, and 9TH
er species of Composition; Recapitulatlons


Trims .-Board and tuition, in any OF the fore.
going branches, $685. per quarter; or, IT paid
in advance, $50. Music, including the use OF
piano, Sl2, French, by one OF the best masters,
Sc per quarter. Moderate extra charges for
Drawing and other ornamental branches


The discipline of the school is mild, parental,
and christian Particular attention is paid not
only to the manners of the young ladies', but to
their moral and religious instruction. They are
regularly conducted to such places OF worship
and Sunday Schools as their parents and guar
dians approve. Exercise and recreation, beng
essential to the preservation OF health and OF
mental energy, occupy the intervals of time not
devoted to study The institution, in all its de-
partmcnts, is conducted in manner which it
is hoped, will meet the entire appreciation OF its
patrons.

S7OHN BANCROFT, having removed from


- Brandywine Bridge, to Providence Facto-
ry, Delaware Co. Pa, takes this means to in
form his friends and the public generally. that
he there continues the Carding of Wool, for all
those who are pleased To favor him with their
custom; and that he hopes by strict atte ntion and
punctuality, to merit continuance of pub
lie patronage lie also takes this opportunity
to inform those to whose favor he was indebted
for work in this line, while at Brandywinc Bridge
that all wool left orhm to card, at ohm Torbert's
Store, or at the soap Factory of Trainton & Ban
croft, Wilmington, or at VIM. MCauley's Store,
Brandy zine, will he taken from thence once cv-
cry week, and, being carded, will be punctualy
retuned the week following; hoping, by the a
bove arrangement, and punctually i'll the return
and good performance of the work confded to
him, they may be induced to continue their IA
YOURS.

After the Goth May next, the Saturday Herald
printed at Baltimore, by Mr.. Samuel Sands, will
change its present form, being a folio, to quar-
to sheet, and assume the title OF the "North A.
merican, or Weekly Journal of Politics, Science
and Literaturc"-to be issued every Saturday, at
81 per annum in advance. We have no doubt
the North American will be valuable weekly
Journal, as the proprietor is disposed to spare
neither pains nor expense to render 1t every way
entitled to the patronage of liberal public


We will, with pleasure, receive the names OF
any persons who may feel disposedto patrohi-e
the NORTH American.


The s'.lrieL and Ladies' Literary Gareffe, q
scmi.monthly publication, has just issued from
the Philadelphia press, published for the Editor
by Elwood Walter, No II, Market-st


The ARIEL is intended to be an interesting
and agreeable companion for the Ladies, devot,
ed to Literature and the Arts; containing sy-
nopss of all that is passing IN the poiite' INC
fashionable, and the literary world, with sum
mary Of news. Original Essays, choice l"tes'
select pieces of Poetry, sketches OF female char
acter, and other pleasing matter VIII occupy IT'S
pages.


The Editor promises that no labor or expense
will be spared to make it q cheap and valuable
vister in the hands oflltcrary ladies' Measures
have been taken to secure the best periodicals. OF
the day, from which extracts, calculated to I'M
prove the female mind, will be freely taken lie
is determined to make it acceptable to the La
Mes. the uncommonly low price at which It IS
published, One Doiiar yearly, must place 1t with
in every ones reach,


If sufficient patronage is extended, the Arei
will be issued ,ceehty, at the end ofthree months


The subscription is payable in advance, and
all letters must be post paid, and addressed to
Ellwood Walter, No, q, Market-st. Philadcl-
phis, Who is Agent for the Editor.


Any person who viii procure six subscribers,
and remit the money, shall receive copy gratis,
for one year

Pumpkins, if steam boiled, are rich food
for swine. the seeds should be taken out. as
they prove injurious to these animals. They
are valuable, as affording an early supply of
food for feeding horses and tattening all
sorts of cattle in the fall and fore part OF the
winter, before the rutabaga crop should be
used.


To save the seed pure, plant the several
kinds at as great distance from each other
as possible. The summer and winter squash
es. if they flower near together, will degen-
crate; and the neighborhood of pumpkin
will deteriorate the future progeny OF both

AN ORDIN ANCE for the regulation OF the own


ers, riders, and drivers of carriages, wagons,
carts, draws, and horses, within the Borough ot


ilmington.


SEC l. Be IT ordainedby The BurgesseS md Be-
rough ConcH oc he Bvough IF lpiimington,
That from and after the passing OF this ordinance,
all and every the drivers or driver OF ali stages,
coaches, Wagons carts, drays, and other car
riages of pleasure or bnrthen, driving and passing
in and through the streets, lanes, or alleys OF this
borough, shall keep on that side OF the street,
lane or alley on his or their right hands, respect
lively, in the passing directions and if amy driver
of any such carriage, wagon, cart or drav, shall
drive the same in the middle Of the street, lane
or alley, or on the left hand side Of the same, SO
as to prevent or obstruct another carriage from
passing along said street, every driver so offend
ing shall forfeit and pay for every such oitence, a
sum not exceeding five dollars, nor less than one
dollar, to be recovered with costs, before either
Of the Rurgesscs, in the same manner as debts
under forty shllngs arc by law recoverable, one
moe,v whereof shall be for the use of the person
suing for the same, and the other moicy shall be
for the use of the Borough.


SIC. ,. Ind be IL ttriier ordained, That if
any driver of any such ca,Hiagc, or if any person
riding upon any horse mare or gelding, shall per
nit or suffer the beast or beasts he shall so drive
or ride, TO go in gallop or other imnoderatc
gait, or shall engage in running or racing III any
manner, with the driver or rider otany other car
ragc, horse, mare or gelding, within any of the
I streets, lanes or alleys Of this Borough, every
person so offending, shall forfeit and pay for eve
ry such offence, 4 sum not exceeding Five dol
/ lars nor less than one dollar, to be recovered
with costs, by any person, in the manner and fol
the uses herein before mentioned.


! Src. 5. ind be ii further ordahed, That if any
person shall wlfully permit or suffer any horse
marc or gcltling TO 60 at large through any o
the Streets lanes or alleys oftlis borough, every
person so offending shall forfeit and pay for eve
ry such offence, the sum of one dollar, to be re-
covered with costs, by any person, in the man
ner and for the uses herein before mentioned.


SEC. A. .and be il further ordained, That tn,
Ordinance entitled "An Ordinance to prcven
the accidents and dangers that may happen By
peoples driving their teams out of walk taste
than is herein specified, and persons playing a
long bullets or any other game whereby there
may be damage sustained" passed OH the thirty
first day of August in the year of our LORD on'
thousand seven hundred and fifty-one, be, an,
the same is hereby repealed, made null and void


Passed at the Town Iall-April Z, 1927.


JAMES BROBSON, First Burgess.
(Atcst) J. p. FAIRLAMB,


Clerk ofHe Borough Council

salts, and it will come up three or four days
sooner than if planted in its natural state,
and neither worms, nor birds, nor fowls will
molest 1.-THE discovery was made by &C
cident last year, by farmer in Massachu-
sett., who supposed the salts used were nj
,re. Not hill of two acres planted with
seed thus prepared was touched, while at
least half Of the adjoining field. planted at

FENCES, PASTURES, &c.


Give vo,r fences general review, repair
al i've, cbrs and see that all gates, bars, &c.
80 rsrularlv shut and fastened. Cattle
n.,ylv 1et out from the yard and stables IN
which thew have been wintered, are very
ant 70 wander; and if they get habit OF
rambIing. it is very difficult to contine them.
Send YOUR boys with bats, malets, or other
nroper implements, over your moving
yrouods and pastures, to beat to pieces ana
Snread over the surface of the soil each and
every lump of manure which your cattle
have dropped the last season.--Do NOT lc'
your cattle, on any account, run upon YOU
moving ground in the spring; for the "'s-
chic. they will do by poaching the erouhu,
and biting the young grass 100 ciose' WI, va,
he ten fold more than the advantage they VIII
der;vr from the feed 1t is likewise inJnm-
m,s to pastures TO turn cattle into them too
early in the spring; and most hurtful 10
those PASTURES IN which the grass springs
earliest, as in those which are low and moist.
The cattle cut up the sward with theit lee',
so that it will produce less quantty OF
grass. DR.. Deane observed that the 9oth
OF MAY is early enough to turn cattle INTO
almost any of our pastures. out Oh some
shey should be kept later. The driest pas
sures should be used first, though IN theHi
the grass is shortest, that the poachihS Vi
the ground in the wetsest may be prevent
ed


Loudon saws ",he time of stocking pas
tures in spring, must evidently be earlier or
later. according to the climate, ana N tne
same climate according to the season; and
she state of growth which it is desirable
shat the grass should attain before being
stocked, must, in some degree be determin-
ed by the condition ana description of the
animals to be employed in consuming 1t;
whether they are only in growing state or
approaching to fatness; whether milch cows
or sheen, or mixture OF animals OF diner
ent species. 1t conveys very precise idea
respecting these points, though the remark
itself is Just, to say that the herhaee shouid
not be allowed to rise so high as to permit
the coarser plants to run to seed; ana that
1t is bad management to suffer store STOCK 10
be turned upon full bite. The great OBJ
jects to be aimed at are, that the STOCK, Of
whatever animals it may consist, should be
carried forward faster or slower, according
TO the purposes Of their owner; and that nc
part Of the herbage should be allowed to run
20 waste, or be unproftably consumed
But nothing but careful inspection OF the
land and Of the stock, from time to time, Car
enable any grazer to judge with certainty
what are the best measures tor ATTAINING
thee Notwithstanding cattle" say'
Marshall, (which are forward In flesh, ant
are intended to be finished with grass, may
require full bite at first turning out. bu
Cor cows, working oxen, and rearing cattle
and lean cattle intended to be fatted on grass
a full bite at first turning out is not requisite


With respect to the size of enclosures


csl5 IN nrpfprreU
large ONES for heavy stock. Besides the adj
yantages of shelter both to the animals ant
the herbage, small fields enable the grazie
either to separate his stock into small par
GELS, by which means they feed more q
their ease, or to give the best pastures I
that portion OF them which he wishes I
come earliest to market. The advantage
of moderate sized enclosures are we'll know
in the best grazing counties but the subdl
visions are in some instances much NOR
minute than is consistent with the value c
she ground occupied with fences, or necessa
nv for the improvement OF the stock. In a
cases, says Marshall, where tatting cattle
dairy cows make part OF the stock, an
where situation, soil and water will PERM
every sort os grazing grounds ought IN m
idea, to consist of three compartments. Or
for head stock, (as cows or fatting cattle
one for followers Gas rearing and otner lea
stock } and the third to be shut up to frest
en- for the leading stock.


Large enclosures are in general best
dapt.d for sheep These animals are NJ
only impatient of heat, and liable to be muc
injured by fiies, in small pastures often SUI
rounded by trees and high hedges, but the
are naturally with the exception perhaps


the Leicester variety, much more restle
and easily disturbed than the other speech
of live stock. "Sheep" says Lord kaime
s.love wider range and ought to have
because they delight in short grass: gi'
them eighty OF ninety acres, and any fen


will keep them in: conhne them to fie
of seven or eight acres, and it must be v
ry strong fence that keeps them nth
fields so large as eighty or ninety acres


be advisable only in hilly districts. yet t


general rule is consistent with experien'


with regard to all our least domesticated y


rieties.

The GRAPE VINES arc particularly desery

full articles.headline:
Young Ladies' Boarding School,

A1 wu ,uNGTnN, DELAWARE.
full articles.article:
Az OINs DIA1n " hN''


Under the superintendence and instruction OF
WILLIAM SHERER, assisted by accomplished
female teachers.


The course of instruction pursued at TINS sem
;,,r,- comprises all the useful, and most OF the
ornamental branches of female education. The
daily exercises are photography, Reading, Writ
;nr. Arithmetic, English Grammar, Rhetoric;
Geography and History, ancient and modern,
with constant reference to the best maps and
charts: Construction of maps; use OF the Globes;
Natural History; Natural Philosophy, including
Astronomy and Chemistry, Elements ot Moral
Science


TfeekiD Egerc;Ses. --Biblical Rccitations; Evi-
dences OF Christianity; Letter Writing, and 9TH
er species of Composition; Recapitulatlons


Trims .-Board and tuition, in any OF the fore.
going branches, $685. per quarter; or, IT paid
in advance, $50. Music, including the use OF
piano, Sl2, French, by one OF the best masters,
Sc per quarter. Moderate extra charges for
Drawing and other ornamental branches


The discipline of the school is mild, parental,
and christian Particular attention is paid not
only to the manners of the young ladies', but to
their moral and religious instruction. They are
regularly conducted to such places OF worship
and Sunday Schools as their parents and guar
dians approve. Exercise and recreation, beng
essential to the preservation OF health and OF
mental energy, occupy the intervals of time not
devoted to study The institution, in all its de-
partmcnts, is conducted in manner which it
is hoped, will meet the entire appreciation OF its
patrons.


References - -IKlmiagion--Iev. L. W. Gil
bert; Hon. W. Hall; Hon. Louis MIane: Phild-
d,iphia--Rcv. Dr. Wilson, Rev. DIR Janeway
Mr.. William Janvier, Merchant, James G..
Thompson, Esq. Professor of Languages, Uni
versity of Pennsylvania.


March IS, 1927 26-3m

full articles.headline: WOOL CARDING.
full articles.article:
S7OHN BANCROFT, having removed from


- Brandywine Bridge, to Providence Facto-
ry, Delaware Co. Pa, takes this means to in
form his friends and the public generally. that
he there continues the Carding of Wool, for all
those who are pleased To favor him with their
custom; and that he hopes by strict atte ntion and
punctuality, to merit continuance of pub
lie patronage lie also takes this opportunity
to inform those to whose favor he was indebted
for work in this line, while at Brandywinc Bridge
that all wool left orhm to card, at ohm Torbert's
Store, or at the soap Factory of Trainton & Ban
croft, Wilmington, or at VIM. MCauley's Store,
Brandy zine, will he taken from thence once cv-
cry week, and, being carded, will be punctualy
retuned the week following; hoping, by the a
bove arrangement, and punctually i'll the return
and good performance of the work confded to
him, they may be induced to continue their IA
YOURS.


4lh mo. S, 1897. 29-5m.

full articles.headline: LITERARY NOTICES.
full articles.article:
After the Goth May next, the Saturday Herald
printed at Baltimore, by Mr.. Samuel Sands, will
change its present form, being a folio, to quar-
to sheet, and assume the title OF the "North A.
merican, or Weekly Journal of Politics, Science
and Literaturc"-to be issued every Saturday, at
81 per annum in advance. We have no doubt
the North American will be valuable weekly
Journal, as the proprietor is disposed to spare
neither pains nor expense to render 1t every way
entitled to the patronage of liberal public


We will, with pleasure, receive the names OF
any persons who may feel disposedto patrohi-e
the NORTH American.


The s'.lrieL and Ladies' Literary Gareffe, q
scmi.monthly publication, has just issued from
the Philadelphia press, published for the Editor
by Elwood Walter, No II, Market-st


The ARIEL is intended to be an interesting
and agreeable companion for the Ladies, devot,
ed to Literature and the Arts; containing sy-
nopss of all that is passing IN the poiite' INC
fashionable, and the literary world, with sum
mary Of news. Original Essays, choice l"tes'
select pieces of Poetry, sketches OF female char
acter, and other pleasing matter VIII occupy IT'S
pages.


The Editor promises that no labor or expense
will be spared to make it q cheap and valuable
vister in the hands oflltcrary ladies' Measures
have been taken to secure the best periodicals. OF
the day, from which extracts, calculated to I'M
prove the female mind, will be freely taken lie
is determined to make it acceptable to the La
Mes. the uncommonly low price at which It IS
published, One Doiiar yearly, must place 1t with
in every ones reach,


If sufficient patronage is extended, the Arei
will be issued ,ceehty, at the end ofthree months


The subscription is payable in advance, and
all letters must be post paid, and addressed to
Ellwood Walter, No, q, Market-st. Philadcl-
phis, Who is Agent for the Editor.


Any person who viii procure six subscribers,
and remit the money, shall receive copy gratis,
for one year


G-fsubscriptions received at this Office

full articles.headline: PUMPKINS.
full articles.article:
Pumpkins, if steam boiled, are rich food
for swine. the seeds should be taken out. as
they prove injurious to these animals. They
are valuable, as affording an early supply of
food for feeding horses and tattening all
sorts of cattle in the fall and fore part OF the
winter, before the rutabaga crop should be
used.


To save the seed pure, plant the several
kinds at as great distance from each other
as possible. The summer and winter squash
es. if they flower near together, will degen-
crate; and the neighborhood of pumpkin
will deteriorate the future progeny OF both

AN ORDIN ANCE for the regulation OF the own


ers, riders, and drivers of carriages, wagons,
carts, draws, and horses, within the Borough ot


ilmington.


SEC l. Be IT ordainedby The BurgesseS md Be-
rough ConcH oc he Bvough IF lpiimington,
That from and after the passing OF this ordinance,
all and every the drivers or driver OF ali stages,
coaches, Wagons carts, drays, and other car
riages of pleasure or bnrthen, driving and passing
in and through the streets, lanes, or alleys OF this
borough, shall keep on that side OF the street,
lane or alley on his or their right hands, respect
lively, in the passing directions and if amy driver
of any such carriage, wagon, cart or drav, shall
drive the same in the middle Of the street, lane
or alley, or on the left hand side Of the same, SO
as to prevent or obstruct another carriage from
passing along said street, every driver so offend
ing shall forfeit and pay for every such oitence, a
sum not exceeding five dollars, nor less than one
dollar, to be recovered with costs, before either
Of the Rurgesscs, in the same manner as debts
under forty shllngs arc by law recoverable, one
moe,v whereof shall be for the use of the person
suing for the same, and the other moicy shall be
for the use of the Borough.


SIC. ,. Ind be IL ttriier ordained, That if
any driver of any such ca,Hiagc, or if any person
riding upon any horse mare or gelding, shall per
nit or suffer the beast or beasts he shall so drive
or ride, TO go in gallop or other imnoderatc
gait, or shall engage in running or racing III any
manner, with the driver or rider otany other car
ragc, horse, mare or gelding, within any of the
I streets, lanes or alleys Of this Borough, every
person so offending, shall forfeit and pay for eve
ry such offence, 4 sum not exceeding Five dol
/ lars nor less than one dollar, to be recovered
with costs, by any person, in the manner and fol
the uses herein before mentioned.


! Src. 5. ind be ii further ordahed, That if any
person shall wlfully permit or suffer any horse
marc or gcltling TO 60 at large through any o
the Streets lanes or alleys oftlis borough, every
person so offending shall forfeit and pay for eve
ry such offence, the sum of one dollar, to be re-
covered with costs, by any person, in the man
ner and for the uses herein before mentioned.


SEC. A. .and be il further ordained, That tn,
Ordinance entitled "An Ordinance to prcven
the accidents and dangers that may happen By
peoples driving their teams out of walk taste
than is herein specified, and persons playing a
long bullets or any other game whereby there
may be damage sustained" passed OH the thirty
first day of August in the year of our LORD on'
thousand seven hundred and fifty-one, be, an,
the same is hereby repealed, made null and void


Passed at the Town Iall-April Z, 1927.


JAMES BROBSON, First Burgess.
(Atcst) J. p. FAIRLAMB,


Clerk ofHe Borough Council

full articles.headline: TO FARMERS.
full articles.article:
Soak seed corn in solution of glau6ers
salts, and it will come up three or four days
sooner than if planted in its natural state,
and neither worms, nor birds, nor fowls will
molest 1.-THE discovery was made by &C
cident last year, by farmer in Massachu-
sett., who supposed the salts used were nj
,re. Not hill of two acres planted with
seed thus prepared was touched, while at
least half Of the adjoining field. planted at
he ssma sime, WAS DESTROYED,

full articles.headline: FENCES. PASTURES, &c.
full articles.article:
FENCES, PASTURES, &c.


Give vo,r fences general review, repair
al i've, cbrs and see that all gates, bars, &c.
80 rsrularlv shut and fastened. Cattle
n.,ylv 1et out from the yard and stables IN
which thew have been wintered, are very
ant 70 wander; and if they get habit OF
rambIing. it is very difficult to contine them.
Send YOUR boys with bats, malets, or other
nroper implements, over your moving
yrouods and pastures, to beat to pieces ana
Snread over the surface of the soil each and
every lump of manure which your cattle
have dropped the last season.--Do NOT lc'
your cattle, on any account, run upon YOU
moving ground in the spring; for the "'s-
chic. they will do by poaching the erouhu,
and biting the young grass 100 ciose' WI, va,
he ten fold more than the advantage they VIII
der;vr from the feed 1t is likewise inJnm-
m,s to pastures TO turn cattle into them too
early in the spring; and most hurtful 10
those PASTURES IN which the grass springs
earliest, as in those which are low and moist.
The cattle cut up the sward with theit lee',
so that it will produce less quantty OF
grass. DR.. Deane observed that the 9oth
OF MAY is early enough to turn cattle INTO
almost any of our pastures. out Oh some
shey should be kept later. The driest pas
sures should be used first, though IN theHi
the grass is shortest, that the poachihS Vi
the ground in the wetsest may be prevent
ed


Loudon saws ",he time of stocking pas
tures in spring, must evidently be earlier or
later. according to the climate, ana N tne
same climate according to the season; and
she state of growth which it is desirable
shat the grass should attain before being
stocked, must, in some degree be determin-
ed by the condition ana description of the
animals to be employed in consuming 1t;
whether they are only in growing state or
approaching to fatness; whether milch cows
or sheen, or mixture OF animals OF diner
ent species. 1t conveys very precise idea
respecting these points, though the remark
itself is Just, to say that the herhaee shouid
not be allowed to rise so high as to permit
the coarser plants to run to seed; ana that
1t is bad management to suffer store STOCK 10
be turned upon full bite. The great OBJ
jects to be aimed at are, that the STOCK, Of
whatever animals it may consist, should be
carried forward faster or slower, according
TO the purposes Of their owner; and that nc
part Of the herbage should be allowed to run
20 waste, or be unproftably consumed
But nothing but careful inspection OF the
land and Of the stock, from time to time, Car
enable any grazer to judge with certainty
what are the best measures tor ATTAINING
thee Notwithstanding cattle" say'
Marshall, (which are forward In flesh, ant
are intended to be finished with grass, may
require full bite at first turning out. bu
Cor cows, working oxen, and rearing cattle
and lean cattle intended to be fatted on grass
a full bite at first turning out is not requisite


With respect to the size of enclosures


csl5 IN nrpfprreU
large ONES for heavy stock. Besides the adj
yantages of shelter both to the animals ant
the herbage, small fields enable the grazie
either to separate his stock into small par
GELS, by which means they feed more q
their ease, or to give the best pastures I
that portion OF them which he wishes I
come earliest to market. The advantage
of moderate sized enclosures are we'll know
in the best grazing counties but the subdl
visions are in some instances much NOR
minute than is consistent with the value c
she ground occupied with fences, or necessa
nv for the improvement OF the stock. In a
cases, says Marshall, where tatting cattle
dairy cows make part OF the stock, an
where situation, soil and water will PERM
every sort os grazing grounds ought IN m
idea, to consist of three compartments. Or
for head stock, (as cows or fatting cattle
one for followers Gas rearing and otner lea
stock } and the third to be shut up to frest
en- for the leading stock.


Large enclosures are in general best
dapt.d for sheep These animals are NJ
only impatient of heat, and liable to be muc
injured by fiies, in small pastures often SUI
rounded by trees and high hedges, but the
are naturally with the exception perhaps


the Leicester variety, much more restle
and easily disturbed than the other speech
of live stock. "Sheep" says Lord kaime
s.love wider range and ought to have
because they delight in short grass: gi'
them eighty OF ninety acres, and any fen


will keep them in: conhne them to fie
of seven or eight acres, and it must be v
ry strong fence that keeps them nth
fields so large as eighty or ninety acres


be advisable only in hilly districts. yet t


general rule is consistent with experien'


with regard to all our least domesticated y


rieties.

full articles.headline:
Surveying OF AanA, and
CONVEYANCING.
full articles.article:
THE SUI scriber tenders his services to the
citizens Wilmington, and county of New Castle,
in the capacity of Surveyor Of Land, and Conyey-
ancer, and hopes from his former experience in
Chester county, and by devoting his attention to
that business, that he will be able to give satis-
